results_summary: CPAP demonstrated modest but stable blood pressure reduction in OSA patients and may be helpful as an adjunctive therapy for those with hypertension. However, MRAs and ACEIs/ARBs were more effective in reducing blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA), specifically those with secondary hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test an algorithm to identify patients who tolerate assisted ventilation but still require ongoing mechanical ventilation, focusing on CPAP tolerance as a step in the weaning process.
results_summary: The algorithm successfully identified 25% of enrolled patients as ready for extubation despite clinicians predicting longer ventilation needs, with CPAP tolerance being a key step in the screening process.
population_specificity: Patients on mechanical ventilation in a clinical trial setting.
effective_dosage: CPAP at 0 cmH2O (implied as part of the tolerance trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on blood pressure in patients with systemic hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP significantly reduced 24-hour, daytime, and nighttime systolic and diastolic blood pressure, as well as heart rate, in patients with hypertension and OSA, except when the follow-up period was shorter than 3 months.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied, with effects not observed in studies shorter than 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal cannula therapy (HFNC) was noninferior to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) as the first-line mode of noninvasive respiratory support for acutely ill children.
results_summary: HFNC met the noninferiority criterion compared to CPAP for time to liberation from respiratory support. HFNC also showed significantly lower use of sedation, shorter critical care stays, and shorter hospital stays, though CPAP had a higher rate of nasal trauma.
population_specificity: Acutely ill children aged 0 to 15 years requiring noninvasive respiratory support in pediatric critical care units.
study_duration: Intervention duration varied; median time to liberation was 47.9 hours for CPAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) on cardiac mechanics, specifically left and right ventricular function, in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant improvements in both left and right ventricular global longitudinal strain (GLS) after CPAP treatment, indicating beneficial effects on biventricular function in OSA patients. However, improvements in LV ejection fraction (LVEF) and tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) were less pronounced.
population_specificity: 337 patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) from nine studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between cardiorespiratory polygraphy findings (including CPAP use) and stroke mortality or ischemic event recurrence after ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Among patients with REI ≥30/h, increased central apnea index predicted higher mortality, but not independently. Only 21 stroke patients initiated CPAP treatment, and of those, only one had a new ischemic event.
population_specificity: 204 ischemic stroke patients who underwent cardiorespiratory polygraphy within 48 hours of symptom onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular benefits of CPAP therapy in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), focusing on its impact on left ventricular function, arterial stiffness, and atrial fibrillation.
results_summary: The study highlights that adherence to CPAP therapy reduces the risk of cardiovascular events in OSA patients, particularly in those with resistant hypertension or atrial fibrillation. It emphasizes the importance of timely OSA diagnosis and treatment to mitigate cardiovascular complications.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), particularly those with cardiovascular complications such as resistant hypertension, atrial fibrillation, or nocturnal adverse cardiovascular events.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the essential elements and considerations for applying respiratory support, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure, in critically ill children.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Continuous Positive Airway Pressure's effects but indicates it is one of the noninvasive respiratory support modalities reviewed for treating critically ill children.
population_specificity: Critically ill children admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the validity of an early lung ultrasound (LUS) score in predicting the need for continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in newborns with gestational age ≥33 weeks presenting respiratory distress.
results_summary: The study found that the early LUS score was a good noninvasive predictor of the need for CPAP and surfactant administration, with high sensitivity and specificity at different time points (T0 and T1). The receiver operating characteristic analysis showed strong predictive accuracy (AUC 0.91 at T0 and 0.82 at T1).
population_specificity: Newborns with gestational age ≥33 weeks presenting respiratory distress within 3 hours of life.
study_duration: LUS assessments were performed within 3 hours of life (T0), at 4-6 hours (T1), and at symptom resolution (T2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of the efficacy of oral appliance therapy for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adult patients, including the role of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) requirements.
results_summary: The study found that responders to oral appliance therapy were younger, had smaller neck circumferences, lower BMI, and required lower optimal CPAP levels than non-responders. The type of device did not affect outcomes, and the criterion "AHI <10 and reduction AHI >50%" was significant for predicting treatment success.
population_specificity: Adult patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate CPAP adherence in bariatric surgery patients with newly diagnosed versus pre-existing OSA and its influence on postoperative outcomes.
results_summary: Inadequate CPAP adherence was higher in newly diagnosed OSA patients (73%) compared to pre-existing OSA patients (39%) six months post-surgery. No significant differences were found in cardiopulmonary complications or ICU admissions between the groups.
population_specificity: Obese patients scheduled for bariatric surgery, newly diagnosed or with pre-existing OSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of split-night polysomnography (snPSG) for diagnosing sleep-related breathing disorders (SRBD) and initiating non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in children.
results_summary: The study found that snPSG was technically feasible in children, facilitating SRBD diagnosis and NIV initiation, with a significant reduction in median apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) from 16.6 to 7.6 events/hour. Most children (87.2%) had moderate to severe SRBD, and treatment reduced the severity in many cases.
population_specificity: Children with sleep-related breathing disorders, including those with medical complexity (e.g., central nervous system, musculoskeletal/neuromuscular, and cardiac disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) compared to conventional oxygen therapy (COT) could prevent escalation of respiratory support in patients with COVID-19 pneumonia and mild hypoxaemia.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between HFNO and COT in preventing escalation of respiratory support, clinical recovery rates, ICU admissions, or hospital length of stay.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19 pneumonia and mild hypoxaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pathophysiology of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and the potential for alternative therapies to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in selected patients.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the complex pathophysiology of OSA and its comorbidities but does not provide specific findings on CPAP's effects. It suggests a move toward precision medicine as an alternative to CPAP in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and associated comorbidities (metabolic, cardiovascular, renal, pulmonary, neuropsychiatric).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing research on the impact of OSA on hearing and balance function and assess whether CPAP therapy affects these functions.
results_summary: Most studies showed increased hearing thresholds, absent OAE, and delayed ABR in adults with OSA, while CPAP transiently increased middle ear pressure. Effects on other auditory regions and the vestibular system remain unclear, and research on children is limited.
population_specificity: Adults and children with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers compared the short-term clinical outcomes of preterm infants using two different automated oxygen controllers (OxyGenie and CLiO) to assess their impact on morbidity and NICU stay duration.
results_summary: The OxyGenie group had significantly fewer days on continuous positive airway pressure (8.4 vs. 16.7 days) and invasive ventilation (0 vs. 2.1 days), as well as reduced laser coagulation for ROP and shorter NICU stays compared to the CLiO group. No significant differences were found in other morbidities.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in a tertiary-level neonatal unit in the Netherlands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the key modes of non-invasive respiratory support, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure, for preterm infants, focusing on their mechanisms and clinical benefits.
results_summary: Non-invasive respiratory support, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure, shows modest success in reducing bronchopulmonary dysplasia incidence compared to invasive mechanical ventilation, with improved clinical practice reported in population-based studies.
population_specificity: Preterm infants, particularly those born before 28 weeks of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Information-Motivation-Behavioral (IMB) skills intervention could improve adherence to Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy in patients with moderate-to-severe Obstructive Sleep Apnea Hypopnea Syndrome (OSAHS).
results_summary: The study found that IMB skills intervention significantly improved CPAP adherence in OSAHS patients compared to the control group, with no significant baseline differences between groups. The intervention was deemed suitable for clinical promotion.
population_specificity: Patients primarily diagnosed with moderate-to-severe OSAHS.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of long-term CPAP treatment on disease severity of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in patients with a history of cardiac or cerebrovascular disease.
results_summary: Long-term CPAP use did not result in clinically significant changes in AHI or ODI overall but showed variable effects when stratified by OSA severity. Both CPAP and standard care groups showed reductions in AHI, but there was no significant difference between the groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45-75 years with a history of cardiac or cerebrovascular disease and confirmed OSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in the multimodality treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) and its adherence challenges.
results_summary: CPAP is considered first-line therapy for OSA but faces adherence issues. Nasal surgery can improve CPAP compliance by reducing therapeutic pressure, though its effect on the apnea-hypopnea index remains controversial.
population_specificity: Patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA), including those with varying severity levels (mild to severe).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NHFOV was more effective than NCPAP or NIPPV in reducing the need for invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) after extubation in preterm neonates.
results_summary: The study found that NHFOV slightly reduced the duration of IMV compared to NCPAP and NIPPV, and both NHFOV and NIPPV resulted in a lower risk of reintubation than NCPAP. All three respiratory support techniques were equally safe for preterm neonates.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates between 25 weeks plus 0 days and 32 weeks plus 6 days gestational age, ready for extubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance and complications of superficial femoral midline catheters (SFMC) in COVID-19 patients undergoing Helmet Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (h-CPAP) for Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure (AHRF).
results_summary: The study found that SFMC was generally safe with few immediate complications (e.g., accidental arterial puncture) but noted late complications like catheter-related infections (2.3%) and thrombosis (2.9%). The method was deemed practical for h-CPAP patients despite some risks.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure (AHRF), including those on h-CPAP and severe cases.
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus was on catheter use, not CPAP dosage).
study_duration: Mean dwell time of SFMC was 11.1 ± 9.8 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy on short-term and long-term outcomes in heart failure patients with sleep-disordered breathing.
results_summary: CPAP therapy was found to improve both short-term and long-term outcomes in heart failure patients with sleep-disordered breathing, including obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea, and Cheyne-Stokes respiration. The abstract also notes that adaptive servoventilation (ASV) therapy is not recommended for low-EF heart failure patients with predominant central sleep apnea.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and sleep-disordered breathing (obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea, or Cheyne-Stokes respiration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the prevalence, treatment options, outcomes, and future research directions of Cheyne-Stokes respiration (CSA-CSR) in children, building on adult sleep medicine experience.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the lack of data on CSA-CSR in children, suggesting under-recognition and the absence of routine polysomnographic assessment in pediatric heart failure patients. It calls for further research in this understudied area.
population_specificity: Children with moderate to severe heart failure and CSA-CSR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of CPAP treatment on ambulatory blood pressure in high-risk patients with moderate or severe OSA and cardiovascular disease or multiple cardiovascular risk factors, excluding those with severe sleepiness.
results_summary: CPAP resulted in modest improvements in blood pressure over 6 to 12 months, with a trend toward reduced 24-hour systolic BP, though the difference was not statistically significant. Nocturnal BP showed possibly larger effects, suggesting office BP measurements may underestimate CPAP's impact.
population_specificity: High-risk patients with moderate-severe OSA and cardiovascular disease or multiple cardiovascular risk factors, excluding those with severe sleepiness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an interdisciplinary weight loss and lifestyle intervention combined with CPAP therapy on OSA severity and comorbidities in men with moderate to severe OSA and overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a 51% reduction in AHI at 8 weeks and 57% at 6 months, with 45% no longer requiring CPAP therapy at 8 weeks and 61.8% at 6 months. Greater improvements in body weight, composition, cardiometabolic risk, and quality of life were also observed in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Spanish men aged 18-65 with moderate to severe OSA and a BMI ≥25.
effective_dosage: Not specified (CPAP therapy details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) as an intervention for reducing nocturnal gastroesophageal reflux symptoms.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to recommend the use of nCPAP for reducing nocturnal reflux symptoms, indicating limited efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Adult patients with nocturnal gastroesophageal reflux symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining tolterodine with CPAP therapy is more effective than CPAP alone in treating overactive bladder symptoms in patients with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea syndrome.
results_summary: Combined tolterodine and CPAP therapy showed statistically significant improvements in OAB symptoms and urinary incontinence compared to CPAP alone, though no significant difference was found in total daily urine volume between the groups.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) via polysomnography.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent mask CPAP (ICPAP) and continuous helmet CPAP (HCPAP) on oxygenation and pulmonary complications following major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study compared ICPAP and HCPAP for postoperative pulmonary complications and oxygenation in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair or pancreaticoduodenectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risk of Self-Induced Lung Injury (P-SILI) and ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) by measuring esophageal pressure during Non-invasive respiratory support (NRS) application, including CPAP, in COVID-19 patients with early hypoxemic acute respiratory failure.
results_summary: The study found that in early COVID-19-related respiratory failure, inspiratory effort was not markedly elevated, and CPAP improved oxygenation compared to Venturi mask. CPAP and NIV reduced esophageal pressure (ΔPes) and maintained dynamic transpulmonary driving pressure (ΔPLDyn) within a potentially safe range.
population_specificity: 21 patients with early de-novo respiratory failure due to COVID-19.
effective_dosage: Not specified (30-minute trials of CPAP, HFNC, and NIV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the correlation between lung ultrasound severity scores and bronchiolitis severity, including the need for respiratory support such as Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP).
results_summary: The study found that 71.4% of children with both anterior and posterior subpleural consolidation required CPAP, indicating a significant correlation between lung ultrasound findings and the need for higher respiratory support. The lung ultrasound severity score also correlated significantly with the type and duration of respiratory support and hospital stay.
population_specificity: Children under 2 years old with bronchiolitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of telemonitoring (TMg) in CPAP-treated obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) patients, focusing on parameter accuracy, clinical management, and therapy impacts.
results_summary: TMg is useful for supporting and fine-tuning CPAP efficacy and compliance in newly-diagnosed OSA patients, but limitations in device accuracy for measuring residual respiratory events and leaks exist, and privacy and cost-effectiveness concerns remain.
population_specificity: Newly-diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) patients treated with CPAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal cannula combined with upper-body elevation could serve as an effective alternative postoperative airway management strategy for patients with untreated obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found that high-flow nasal cannula alone or combined with upper-body elevation significantly reduced the flow-based apnea hypopnea index and improved overnight oxygenation in postoperative OSA patients, with the greatest reduction seen in the combined intervention. No harmful events were observed.
population_specificity: Postoperative patients with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
effective_dosage: High-flow nasal cannula at 20 l · min-1 with 40% oxygen concentration.

study_goal: To determine whether heated humidified high-flow nasal cannula (HHHFNC) is noninferior to NCPAP for respiratory support in preterm neonates (GA 28-36 weeks).
results_summary: HHHFNC showed similar efficacy and safety as NCPAP, but noninferiority could not be conclusively proven due to the 95% CI crossing the noninferiority margin. No significant differences were found in secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates (gestational age 28-36 weeks) with respiratory distress soon after birth.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of CPAP compared to no CPAP or sham CPAP in infants and children up to three years of age with acute bronchiolitis.
results_summary: CPAP did not reduce the need for mechanical ventilation but showed a decrease in respiratory rate. The evidence was of low certainty, and effects on other outcomes (e.g., oxygen saturation, pCO₂, hospital stay) were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Infants and children up to 12 months with acute bronchiolitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of SGLT2 inhibitors in treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and their impact on cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The study identified 4 manuscripts involving 475 OSA patients with T2DM, showing that SGLT2 inhibitors have potential positive impacts on OSA by targeting mechanisms involved in its pathogenesis. The conclusion suggests SGLT2 inhibitors are promising for OSA treatment but calls for further research.
population_specificity: OSA patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) therapy was noninferior to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) as the first-line mode of noninvasive respiratory support for critically ill children following extubation.
results_summary: CPAP demonstrated superior efficacy, with a shorter median time to liberation from respiratory support (42.9 hours) compared to HFNC (50.5 hours). Mortality at day 180 was significantly lower with CPAP (2.4%) than HFNC (5.6%), though other secondary outcomes, including reintubation rates, showed no significant differences.
population_specificity: Critically ill children aged 0 to 15 years requiring noninvasive respiratory support within 72 hours of extubation.
study_duration: Intervention duration varied based on time to liberation from respiratory support, with follow-up until day 180.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the benefits of noninvasive neurally adjusted ventilatory assist (NIV-NAVA) versus nasal continuous positive airway pressure (NCPAP) in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in treatment failure or mortality between NIV-NAVA and NCPAP, but NIV-NAVA significantly reduced caffeine use compared to NCPAP. The evidence was insufficient to conclude clear benefits or harms of NIV-NAVA over NCPAP.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prophylactic high-flow nasal therapy (a form of low-level positive airway pressure) improves days alive and at home within 90 days post-surgery compared to standard oxygen therapy, and to assess its cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: The study is an ongoing adaptive trial comparing high-flow nasal therapy to standard oxygen therapy in high-risk cardiac surgery patients, with outcomes to be measured at 90 days post-surgery. No results are reported yet, but the design aims to detect a 2-day increase in days alive and at home.
population_specificity: High-risk cardiac surgery patients post-tracheal extubation.
effective_dosage: High-flow nasal therapy administered for a minimum of 16 hours post-extubation.
study_duration: Minimum 16 hours post-extubation, with follow-up until 90 days after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether helium-oxygen (heliox) reduces the need for Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) or intubation in infants with bronchiolitis.
results_summary: The study found low-quality evidence that heliox does not reduce the need for CPAP or intubation, nor does it shorten hospitalization duration, but it may rapidly relieve respiratory distress symptoms based on M-WCAS scores.
population_specificity: Infants with bronchiolitis (560 participants across six studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare short-term outcomes in preterm infants ≤30 weeks gestation receiving neonatal care, including CPAP, in a middle-income country (India) versus a high-income country (UK).
results_summary: The study found that survival rates for infants ≤28 weeks gestation were significantly lower in the Bengaluru center compared to London, with fewer mothers receiving antenatal steroids in Bengaluru. CPAP was part of the neonatal care, but specific efficacy data for CPAP alone were not highlighted.
population_specificity: Preterm infants ≤30 weeks gestation admitted to tertiary neonatal units in Bengaluru, India, and London, UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the interaction among OSA, CPAP, and CV/CeV medications, and the effects of these medications on major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events and survival in patients with comorbid OSA and CV/CeV disease.
results_summary: CPAP treatment neutralized the negative effects of OSA by relieving chronic intermittent hypoxia, particularly in patients with good CPAP adherence. ACE inhibitors and nitrates were associated with decreased survival in some patient groups, but CPAP mitigated these effects.
population_specificity: Patients aged 45-75 years with comorbid OSA and cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease.
interactions: ACE inhibitors and nitrates showed negative effects on survival in some groups, but CPAP mitigated these effects. Clopidogrel and nitrates decreased survival in the usual care group but not in the CPAP group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate sleep disorders, particularly obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), in individuals with Down syndrome and identify treatment options, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP).
results_summary: The study found that OSA is the primary sleep disorder in individuals with Down syndrome, and CPAP is one of the main treatment options, alongside surgery and weight control. Cognitive dysfunction was noted in patients with sleep-disordered breathing, but CPAP's specific efficacy was not detailed beyond its inclusion as a treatment.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with Down syndrome under 18 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations between obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and various ocular health conditions, as well as the potential impact of CPAP therapy on these conditions, particularly glaucoma risk and management.
results_summary: The study found conflicting evidence on OSA's associations with several eye diseases, including glaucoma, and highlighted the need for further investigation into CPAP's ocular hypertensive effects. It also noted reports of ocular surface complications due to poorly fitting CPAP masks.
population_specificity: Individuals with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: To compare the efficacy and safety of nebulized poractant alfa (at 200 and 400 mg/kg doses) combined with nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) versus CPAP alone in premature infants with respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the primary outcome (need for endotracheal surfactant and/or mechanical ventilation within 72 hours) between the intervention groups and CPAP alone. Secondary respiratory outcomes also showed no differences, and the intervention did not reduce respiratory failure likelihood.
population_specificity: Premature infants at 28 weeks gestation or older with diagnosed respiratory distress syndrome.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg of nebulized poractant alfa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tactile stimulation versus routine handling in term and preterm infants with inadequate respiratory effort at birth, particularly those on continuous positive airway pressure.
results_summary: The study found a reduction in tracheal intubation in preterm infants receiving tactile stimulation compared to no stimulation (12 of 164 vs. 14 of 79, risk ratio 0.41), but the certainty of evidence was very low due to limited data and high risk of bias in one of the two eligible studies.
population_specificity: Preterm infants on continuous positive airway pressure with clinical indications for tactile stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative diagnosis and CPAP therapy reduce postoperative risks in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and examine the impact of OSA severity on outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative diagnosis and CPAP use reduced postoperative respiratory and cardiac complications in OSA patients, with risks increasing with OSA severity. CPAP therapy was associated with lower odds of adverse events, though the conclusions require cautious interpretation due to data limitations.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) undergoing surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review potential pharmacological alternatives to CPAP for treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about CPAP's effects, focusing instead on pharmacological treatments for OSA.
population_specificity: Not specified (general OSA patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of delivery room continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in reducing the risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) or mortality in preterm neonates.
results_summary: High certainty of evidence showed that delivery room CPAP compared with intubation with or without routine surfactant significantly reduced the risk of BPD or mortality at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age (RR, 0.80 [95% CI, 0.68-0.94]). Avoiding endotracheal tube placement with CPAP and less invasive surfactant administration also decreased the risk (RR, 0.90 [95% CI, 0.82-0.99]).
population_specificity: Preterm neonates at risk for bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) could reduce cardiovascular stress and D-dimer levels in individuals with Marfan syndrome (MFS) and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP effectively eliminated OSA (reducing AHI from 20±17 to 3±2 events/h) and was associated with reduced cardiovascular stress, though D-dimer results were not explicitly stated in the abstract.
population_specificity: 16 individuals with Marfan syndrome (MFS) without aortic dissection (10 male, 6 female; age 36±13 years; aortic diameter 4±1 cm).
study_duration: Two nights (one baseline, one with CPAP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of prehospital noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) versus standard care in reducing intubation rates and hospital/ICU stays for adult patients with severe respiratory distress.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that NIPPV significantly reduced intubation rates and shortened hospital and ICU stays compared to standard care, though it did not affect in-hospital mortality. The results suggest clinical benefits of NIPPV for severe respiratory distress.
population_specificity: Adult patients with severe respiratory distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in managing sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) in patients with heart failure (HF), particularly its impact on mortality and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract indicates limited evidence for CPAP's efficacy in improving mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). It highlights the need for further well-designed studies to identify specific phenotypes of CSA/OSA in HF patients and determine effective therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF) and sleep-disordered breathing (SDB), including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and central sleep apnea (CSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) on retinal microvascular function by comparing continued CPAP use versus sham CPAP.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of CPAP withdrawal and return of OSA on retinal microvascular responses, with no significant change in arteriolar response to flickering light between sham CPAP and continued CPAP groups. This suggests OSA may have different effects on macrovascular and microvascular endothelial function.
population_specificity: Patients with known moderate-to-severe OSA established on CPAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the comfort level of preterm infants receiving fentanyl versus no fentanyl during the LISA procedure (surfactant administration with nCPAP).
results_summary: Preterm infants receiving low-dose fentanyl during the LISA procedure showed significantly higher comfort (88.23% vs. 47.05%) without increased complications. No differences were observed in secondary outcomes like hsPDA, IVH, or BPD/mortality.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (28+0–33+6 weeks gestation) with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
study_duration: Single administration during the LISA procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of non-invasive respiratory support, including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP), in managing transient tachypnoea of the newborn (TTN).
results_summary: The evidence is very uncertain regarding CPAP's effect on reducing the duration of tachypnoea compared to free-flow oxygen therapy (MD -21.1 hours, 95% CI -22.9 to -19.3, very low certainty evidence). No clear conclusions could be drawn about its impact on the need for mechanical ventilation due to limited data.
population_specificity: Term (> 37 weeks' gestation) or late preterm (34 to 36 weeks' gestation) infants with TTN.
study_duration: Intervention administered within the first 48 hours of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bidirectional relationship between endocrine disorders and OSA, and assess whether CPAP treatment improves endocrine disturbances.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP's effects on endocrine disturbances remain unclear due to confounding factors, though treatment of underlying endocrine disorders can sometimes improve or cure OSA.
population_specificity: Patients with endocrine disorders (obesity, hypothyroidism, acromegaly, Cushing syndrome, type 1 and 2 diabetes) and OSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a patient-centered sleep study report (PCSR) for OSA patients and assess its impact on patient understanding and perceived physician interaction.
results_summary: The PCSR improved patient understanding and perceived patient-physician interaction compared to standard care, but its effect on therapy compliance requires further evaluation.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cardiovascular benefits of combining weight loss with CPAP compared to CPAP or weight loss alone in patients with obstructive sleep apnea.
results_summary: The combined therapy of CPAP and weight loss significantly reduced systolic blood pressure and triglyceride levels more than CPAP alone, but adding CPAP to weight loss did not further improve blood pressure or lipid values.
population_specificity: 2627 patients with obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPAP treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) improves glycemic measures in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: CPAP treatment did not result in sustained improved glycemic control compared to sham in the intent-to-treat analysis, but greater CPAP adherence was associated with greater improvements in glycemic control, particularly with usage ≥7 hours per day.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and obstructive sleep apnea (N = 98).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence measured as percentage of days with ≥4 hours use and average hours/day of use).
